entities.title: Magnús Óláfsson
entities.description: Magnús Óláfsson was a King of Mann and the Isles. He was a son of Óláfr Guðrøðarson, King of the Isles, and a member of the Crovan dynasty. Magnús' realm encompassed Mann and parts of the Hebrides. Some leading members of Magnús' family—such as his father—styled themselves "King of the Isles"; other members—such as Magnús and his brothers—styled themselves "King of Mann and the Isles". Although ki

heading: Deaths
txt: Hugh Despenser the Younger, English courtier (b. 1296)

entities.title: Hugh Despenser the Younger
entities.description: Hugh le Despenser, 1st Baron le Despenser, also referred to as "the Younger Despenser", was the son and heir of Hugh le Despenser, Earl of Winchester by his wife Isabella de Beauchamp, daughter of William de Beauchamp, 9th Earl of Warwick. He rose to national prominence as royal chamberlain and a favourite of Edward II of England. Despenser made many enemies amongst the nobility of England. After

heading: Deaths
txt: Elizabeth of Lancaster, Duchess of Exeter, (b. c. 1363)

entities.title: Elizabeth of Lancaster, Duchess of Exeter
entities.description: Elizabeth of Lancaster was the third child of John of Gaunt, 1st Duke of Lancaster, and his first wife Blanche of Lancaster. Elizabeth was made a Lady of the Garter in 1378.

heading: Deaths
txt: Jean de Dunois, French soldier (b. 1402)

entities.title: Jean de Dunois
entities.description: Jean d'Orléans, Count of Dunois, known as the "Bastard of Orléans" or simply Jean de Dunois, was a French military leader during the Hundred Years' War who participated in military campaigns with Joan of Arc. He was the illegitimate son of Louis I, Duke of Orléans – himself a son of King Charles V of France – and his mistress Mariette d'Enghien. His nickname, the "Bastard of Orléans", was a term o

heading: Deaths
txt: Loys of Gruuthuse, Earl of Winchester (b. c. 1427)

entities.title: Loys of Gruuthuse
entities.description: Louis de Bruges, Lord of Gruuthuse, Prince of Steenhuijs, Earl of Winchester, was a Flemish courtier, bibliophile, soldier and nobleman. He was awarded the title of Earl of Winchester by King Edward IV of England in 1472, and was Stadtholder of Holland and Zeeland 1462–77.

entities.title: Winchester
entities.description: Winchester is a cathedral city in Hampshire, England. The city lies at the heart of the wider City of Winchester, a local government district, at the western end of the South Downs National Park, on the River Itchen. It is 60 miles (97 km) south-west of London and 14 miles (23 km) from Southampton, the closest other city. At the 2011 census, Winchester had a population of 45,184. The wider City of

heading: Deaths
txt: Mingyi Nyo, Burmese ruler (b. 1459)

entities.title: Mingyi Nyo
entities.description: Mingyi Nyo was the founder of Toungoo dynasty of Burma (Myanmar). Under his 45-year leadership (1485–1530), Toungoo (Taungoo), grew from a remote backwater vassal state of Ava Kingdom to a small but stable independent kingdom. In 1510, he declared Toungoo's independence from its nominal overlord Ava. He skillfully kept his small kingdom out of the chaotic warfare plaguing Upper Burma. Toungoo's st

heading: Deaths
txt: Johannes Oecolampadius, German theologian and reformer (b. 1482)

entities.title: Johannes Oecolampadius
entities.description: Johannes Oecolampadius was a German Protestant reformer in the Reformed tradition from the Electoral Palatinate. He was the leader of the Protestant faction in the Baden Disputation of 1526, and he was one of the founders of Protestant theology, engaging in disputes with Erasmus, Zwingli, Luther and Martin Bucer. Calvin adopted his view on the eucharist dispute.

heading: Deaths
txt: John Knox, Scottish pastor and theologian (b. 1510)

entities.title: John Knox
entities.description: John Knox was a Scottish minister, theologian, and writer who was a leader of the country's Reformation. He was the founder of the Presbyterian Church of Scotland.

heading: Deaths
txt: René de Birague, French cardinal (b. 1506)

entities.title: René de Birague
entities.description: René de Birague was an Italian patrician who became a French cardinal and chancellor.

heading: Deaths
txt: Sethus Calvisius, German composer and theorist (b. 1556)

entities.title: Sethus Calvisius
entities.description: Sethus Calvisius or Setho Calvisio, originally Seth Kalwitz, was a German music theorist, composer, chronologer, astronomer, and teacher of the late Renaissance.

heading: Deaths
txt: Walatta Petros, saint in the Ethiopian Orthodox Tewahedo Church (b. 1592)

entities.title: Walatta Petros
entities.description: Walatta Petros is a female saint in the Ethiopian Orthodox Tewahedo Church. Her hagiography, The Life-Struggles of Walatta Petros was written in 1672. She is known for resisting conversion to Roman Catholicism, forming many religious communities, and performing miracles for those seeking asylum from kings.

heading: Deaths
txt: Manuel Cardoso, Portuguese organist and composer (b. 1566)

entities.title: Manuel Cardoso
entities.description: Manuel Cardoso was a Portuguese composer and organist. With Duarte Lobo and John IV of Portugal, he represented the "golden age" of Portuguese polyphony.

heading: Deaths
txt: Guru Tegh Bahadur, Indian guru (b. 1621)

entities.title: Guru Tegh Bahadur
entities.description: Guru Tegh Bahadur (Gurmukhi: ਗੁਰੂ ਤੇਗ ਬਹਾਦਰ, pronunciation: was the ninth of ten Gurus who founded the Sikh religion and the leader of Sikhs from 1665 until his beheading in 1675. He was born in Amritsar, Punjab, India in 1621 and was the youngest son of Guru Hargobind Sahib, the sixth Sikh guru. Considered a principled and fearless warrior, he was a learned spiritual scholar and poet whose 115 hy

heading: Deaths
txt: Johann Adam Reincken, Dutch-German organist and composer (b. 1623)

entities.title: Johann Adam Reincken
entities.description: Johann Adam Reincken was a Dutch/German organist and composer. He was one of the most important composers of the 17th century, a friend of Dieterich Buxtehude and a major influence on Johann Sebastian Bach; however, very few of his works survive to this day.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ulrika Eleonora, Queen of Sweden (b. 1688)

entities.title: Ulrika Eleonora, Queen of Sweden
entities.description: Ulrika Eleonora or Ulrica Eleanor, known as Ulrika Eleonora the Younger, was Queen of Sweden, reigning in her own right from 5 December 1718 until her abdication on 29 February 1720 in favour of her husband King Frederick, and then as his consort until her death.

heading: Deaths
txt: Charles-Jean-François Hénault, French historian and author (b. 1685)

entities.title: Charles-Jean-François Hénault
entities.description: Charles-Jean-François Hénault was a French writer and historian.

heading: Deaths
txt: Lorenzo Ricci, Italian religious leader, 18th Superior General of the Society of Jesus (b. 1703)

entities.title: Lorenzo Ricci
entities.description: Lorenzo Ricci, S.J. was an Italian Jesuit, elected the eighteenth Superior General of the Society of Jesus. He was also the last before the suppression of the Jesuits in 1773.

entities.title: Superior General of the Society of Jesus
entities.description: The Superior General of the Society of Jesus is the official title of the leader of the Society of Jesus – the Roman Catholic religious order which is also known as the Jesuits. He is generally addressed as Father General. The position sometimes carries the nickname of the Black Pope, because of his responsibility for the largest Catholic, male religious order and is contrasted to the white garb o

heading: Deaths
txt: James Caldwell, American minister (b. 1734)

entities.title: James Caldwell (clergyman)
entities.description: James Caldwell was a Presbyterian minister who played a prominent part in the American Revolution.

heading: Deaths
txt: Clément Charles François de Laverdy, French lawyer and politician, French Minister of Finance (b. 1723)

entities.title: Clément Charles François de Laverdy
entities.description: Clément Charles François de Laverdy was a French statesman.

entities.title: List of Finance Ministers of France
entities.description: This is a list of Ministers of Finance of France, including the equivalent positions of Superintendent of Finances and Controller-General of Finances during the Ancien Régime. The position of Superintendent of Finances was abolished following the arrest of Nicolas Fouquet; his powers were transferred to First Minister Jean-Baptiste Colbert, who would become ex officio Controller-General of Financ

heading: Deaths
txt: Franz Moritz von Lacy, Austrian field marshal (b. 1725)

entities.title: Franz Moritz von Lacy
entities.description: Franz Moritz Graf von Lacy was a Baltic German-born Austrian military leader, he was the son of Count Peter von Lacy and was a famous Austrian field marshal. He served during the reign of Maria Theresa and was a close friend to Joseph II, Holy Roman Emperor, becoming one of the latter's advisers. Lacy was made a Count of the Holy Roman Empire.

heading: Deaths
txt: Philip Hamilton, Oldest son of Alexander Hamilton (b. 1782)

heading: Deaths
txt: Joseph Brant, American tribal leader (b. 1742)

entities.title: Joseph Brant
entities.description: Thayendanegea or Joseph Brant was a Mohawk military and political leader, based in present-day New York, who was closely associated with Great Britain during and after the American Revolution. Perhaps the Native American of his generation best known to the Americans and British, he met many of the most significant Anglo-American people of the age, including both George Washington and King George I

heading: Deaths
txt: William Lamb, 2nd Viscount Melbourne, English politician, Prime Minister of the United Kingdom (b. 1779)

entities.title: William Lamb, 2nd Viscount Melbourne
entities.description: William Lamb, 2nd Viscount Melbourne,, in some sources called Henry William Lamb, was a British Whig statesman who served as Home Secretary (1830–1834) and Prime Minister. He is best known for being prime minister in Queen Victoria's early years and coaching her in the ways of politics, acting almost as her private secretary. Historians have concluded that Melbourne does not rank highly as a Prime

entities.title: Prime Minister of the United Kingdom
entities.description: The prime minister of the United Kingdom is the head of government in the United Kingdom. The prime minister chairs the Cabinet and selects its ministers, and advises the sovereign on the exercise of much of the Royal Prerogative. As modern prime ministers hold office by virtue of their ability to command the confidence of the House of Commons, they typically sit as a Member of Parliament and lead

heading: Deaths
txt: Comte de Lautréamont, Uruguayan-French poet and author (b. 1846)

entities.title: Comte de Lautréamont
entities.description: Comte de Lautréamont was the nom de plume of Isidore Lucien Ducasse, a French poet born in Uruguay. His only works, Les Chants de Maldoror and Poésies, had a major influence on modern arts and literature, particularly on the Surrealists and the Situationists. Ducasse died at the age of 24.

heading: Deaths
txt: Nicolás Avellaneda, Argentinian journalist and politician, 8th President of Argentina (b. 1837)

entities.title: Nicolás Avellaneda
entities.description: Nicolás Remigio Aurelio Avellaneda Silva was an Argentine politician and journalist, and President of Argentina from 1874 to 1880. Avellaneda's main projects while in office were banking and education reform, leading to Argentina's economic growth. The most important events of his government were the Conquest of the Desert and the transformation of the Buenos Aires into a federal district.

entities.title: President of Argentina
entities.description: The President of Argentina, officially known as the President of the Argentine Nation, is both head of state and head of government of Argentina. Under the national Constitution, the President is also the chief executive of the federal government and Commander-in-Chief of the Armed Forces.

heading: Deaths
txt: August Belmont, German-American banker and politician, 16th United States Ambassador to the Netherlands (b. 1816)

entities.title: August Belmont
entities.description: August Belmont Sr. was a German-American politician, financier, foreign diplomat, and party chairman of the Democratic National Committee during the 1860s, and later a horse-breeder and racehorse owner. He was the founder and namesake of the Belmont Stakes, third leg of the Triple Crown series of American thoroughbred horse racing.

entities.title: United States Ambassador to the Netherlands
entities.description: The United States diplomatic mission to the Netherlands consists of the embassy located in The Hague and a consular office located in Amsterdam.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ludwik Teichmann, Polish anatomist (b. 1823)

entities.title: Ludwik Teichmann
entities.description: Ludwik Karol Teichmann-Stawiarski (1823–1895) was a Polish anatomist and discoverer of a new way of research in forensic medicine, after whom Teichmann crystals are called.

heading: Deaths
txt: Hiram Maxim, American-English engineer, invented the Maxim gun (b. 1840)

entities.title: Hiram Maxim
entities.description: Sir Hiram Stevens Maxim was a British/American inventor best known as the creator of the first automatic machine gun, the Maxim gun. Maxim held patents on numerous mechanical devices such as hair-curling irons, a mousetrap, and steam pumps. Maxim laid claim to inventing the lightbulb.

entities.title: Maxim gun
entities.description: The Maxim gun is a recoil-operated machine gun invented by Sir Hiram Stevens Maxim in 1884; the weapon became the first automatic firearm in production by Vickers, which used .303 British bullets and a recoil-operating firing system, and required water cooling.

heading: Deaths
txt: Lado Aleksi-Meskhishvili, Georgian actor and director (b. 1857)

entities.title: Lado Aleksi-Meskhishvili
entities.description: Vladimir (Lado) Alexi-Meskhishvili, Lado Meskhishivili, or Alekseev-Meskhiev, was a Georgian theater actor and director. He is buried at the Didube Pantheon in Tbilisi. His son was Shalva Aleksi-Meskhishvili, a Georgian jurist and politician.

heading: Deaths
txt: Alexandru Macedonski, Romanian author and poet (b. 1854)

heading: Deaths
txt: Erskine Childers, Irish soldier, journalist, and author (b. 1870)

entities.title: Erskine Childers (author)
entities.description: Robert Erskine Childers DSC, usually known as Erskine Childers, was an English-born Irish writer, whose works included the influential novel The Riddle of the Sands. He became a supporter of Irish Republicanism and smuggled guns into Ireland in his sailing yacht Asgard. He was executed by the authorities of the nascent Irish Free State during the Irish Civil War. He was the son of British Oriental

heading: Deaths
txt: Georges Clemenceau, French physician, publisher, and politician, 72nd Prime Minister of France (b. 1841)

entities.title: Georges Clemenceau
entities.description: Georges Eugène Benjamin Clemenceau was a French statesman who served as Prime Minister of France from 1906 to 1909 and again from 1917 until 1920. A strong advocate of Separation of Church and State and opposition to colonisation, he played a central role in the politics of the Third Republic, most notably successfully leading the country through the end of the First World War.

entities.title: List of Prime Ministers of France
entities.description: The head of the Government of France has been called Prime Minister of France since 1959, when Michel Debré became the first officeholder appointed under the Fifth Republic.

heading: Deaths
txt: Doris Miller, American soldier and chef, Navy Cross recipient (b. 1919)

entities.title: Doris Miller
entities.description: Doris "Dorie" Miller was a United States Navy cook third class who was killed in action during World War II. He was the first black American to be awarded the Navy Cross, the second highest decoration for valor in combat after the Medal of Honor.

entities.title: Navy Cross
entities.description: The Navy Cross is the United States Navy and United States Marine Corps' second-highest military decoration awarded for sailors and marines who distinguish themselves for extraordinary heroism in combat with an armed enemy force. The medal is equivalent to the Army's Distinguished Service Cross, the Air Force and Space Force's Air Force Cross, and the Coast Guard Cross.

heading: Deaths
txt: Anna Jarvis, American founder of Mother's Day (b. 1864)

entities.title: Anna Jarvis
entities.description: Anna Maria Jarvis was the founder of Mother's Day in the United States. Her mother had frequently expressed a desire for the establishment of such a holiday, and after her mother's death, Jarvis led the movement for the commemoration. However, as the years passed, Jarvis grew disenchanted with the growing commercialization of the observation and even attempted to have Mother's Day rescinded. She d

entities.title: Mother's Day
entities.description: Mother's Day is a celebration honoring the mother of the family, as well as motherhood, maternal bonds, and the influence of mothers in society. It is celebrated on various days in many parts of the world, most commonly in the months of March or May. It complements similar celebrations honoring family members, such as Father's Day, Siblings Day, and Grandparents Day.

heading: Deaths
txt: Mamie Dillard, African American educator, clubwoman and suffragist (b. 1874)

entities.title: Mamie Dillard
entities.description: Mary "Mamie" J. Dillard (1874-1954) was an American educator, clubwoman and suffragist.

heading: Deaths
txt: Guido Cantelli, Italian conductor (b. 1920)

entities.title: Guido Cantelli
entities.description: Guido Cantelli was an Italian orchestral conductor. He was named Musical Director of La Scala, Milan in November 1956 but his promising career was cut short only one week later by his death at the age of 36 in an airplane crash in Paris, France.

heading: Deaths
txt: Diego Rivera, Mexican painter and sculptor (b. 1886)

entities.title: Diego Rivera
entities.description: Diego María de la Concepción Juan Nepomuceno Estanislao de la Rivera y Barrientos Acosta y Rodríguez, known as Diego Rivera, was a prominent Mexican painter. His large frescoes helped establish the mural movement in Mexican and international art.

heading: Deaths
txt: Robert Cecil, 1st Viscount Cecil of Chelwood, English lawyer and politician, Chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster, Nobel Prize laureate (b. 1864)

entities.title: Robert Cecil, 1st Viscount Cecil of Chelwood
entities.description: Edgar Algernon Robert Gascoyne-Cecil, 1st Viscount Cecil of Chelwood,, known as Lord Robert Cecil from 1868 to 1923, was a British lawyer, politician and diplomat. He was one of the architects of the League of Nations and a defender of it, whose service to the organisation saw him awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1937.

entities.title: Chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster
entities.description: The Chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster is a ministerial office in the Government of the United Kingdom that includes as part of its duties the administration of the estates and rents of the Duchy of Lancaster.

entities.title: Nobel Peace Prize
entities.description: The Nobel Peace Prize is one of the five Nobel Prizes established by the will of Swedish industrialist, inventor, and armaments manufacturer Alfred Nobel, along with the prizes in Chemistry, Physics, Physiology or Medicine, and Literature. Since March 1901, it has been awarded annually to those who have "done the most or the best work for fraternity between nations, for the abolition or reduction

heading: Deaths
txt: Dally Messenger, Australian rugby player, cricketer, and sailor (b. 1883)

entities.title: Dally Messenger
entities.description: Herbert Henry Messenger, nicknamed "Dally" and sometimes "The Master" was one of Australasia's first professional rugby footballers, recognised as one of the greatest-ever players in either code. He played for New South Wales in the first match run by the newly created 'New South Wales Rugby Football League' which had just split away from the established New South Wales Rugby Football Union.

heading: Deaths
txt: Grand Duchess Olga Alexandrovna of Russia (b. 1882)

entities.title: Grand Duchess Olga Alexandrovna of Russia
entities.description: Grand Duchess Olga Alexandrovna of Russia was the youngest child of Tsar Alexander III of Russia and younger sister of Emperor Nicholas II.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ruth Chatterton, American actress (b. 1892)

entities.title: Ruth Chatterton
entities.description: Ruth Chatterton was an American stage, film, and television actress, aviatrix and novelist. She was at her most popular in the early to mid-1930s, and in the same era gained prominence as an aviator, one of the few female pilots in the United States at the time. In the late 1930s, Chatterton retired from film acting but continued her career on the stage. She had several TV roles beginning in the l

heading: Deaths
txt: Lee Harvey Oswald, American assassin of John F. Kennedy (b. 1939)

entities.title: Lee Harvey Oswald
entities.description: Lee Harvey Oswald was a former U.S. Marine who assassinated United States president John F. Kennedy on November 22, 1963.

entities.title: John F. Kennedy
entities.description: John Fitzgerald Kennedy, often referred to by his initials JFK, was an American politician who served as the 35th president of the United States from 1961 until his assassination in 1963. Kennedy served at the height of the Cold War, and the majority of his work as president concerned relations with the Soviet Union and Cuba. A Democrat, Kennedy represented Massachusetts in both houses of the U.S.

heading: Deaths
txt: Abdullah III Al-Salim Al-Sabah, Kuwaiti ruler (b. 1895)

entities.title: Abdullah III Al-Salim Al-Sabah
entities.description: Sheikh Abdullah Al-Salim Al-Sabah was the eleventh ruler of Kuwait, the first Emir of the State of Kuwait, and commander-in-chief of Kuwait Military Forces from 29 January 1950 until his death.

heading: Deaths
txt: D. A. Levy, American poet and publisher (b. 1942)

entities.title: D. A. Levy
entities.description: d.a. levy, born Darryl Alfred Levey, was an American poet, artist, and alternative publisher active during the 1960s, based in Cleveland, Ohio.

heading: Deaths
txt: John Neihardt, American author and poet (b. 1881)

entities.title: John Neihardt
entities.description: John Gneisenau Neihardt was an American writer and poet, amateur historian and ethnographer. Born at the end of the American settlement of the Plains, he became interested in the lives of those who had been a part of the European-American migration, as well as the Indigenous peoples whom they had displaced.

heading: Deaths
txt: Herbert Agar, American journalist and historian (b. 1897)

entities.title: Herbert Agar
entities.description: Herbert Sebastian Agar was an American journalist and historian, and an editor of the Louisville Courier-Journal.

heading: Deaths
txt: George Raft, American actor and dancer (b. 1901)

heading: Deaths
txt: Molly Reilly, Canadian aviator (b. 1922)

heading: Deaths
txt: Henrietta Hill Swope, American astronomer and academic (b. 1902)

heading: Deaths
txt: Barack Obama, Sr., Kenyan economist and academic, father of Barack Obama, 44th President of the United States (b. 1936)

entities.title: Barack Obama, Sr.
entities.description: Barack Hussein Obama Sr. was a Kenyan senior governmental economist and the father of Barack Obama, the 44th president of the United States. He is a central figure of his son's memoir, Dreams from My Father (1995). Obama married in 1954 and had two children with his first wife, Kezia. He was selected for a special program to attend college in the United States and studied at the University of Hawa

entities.title: Barack Obama
entities.description: Barack Hussein Obama II is an American politician and attorney who served as the 44th president of the United States from 2009 to 2017. A member of the Democratic Party, Obama was the first African-American president of the United States. He previously served as a U.S. senator from Illinois from 2005 to 2008 and as an Illinois state senator from 1997 to 2004.

heading: Deaths
txt: Jehane Benoît, Canadian journalist and author (b. 1904)

entities.title: Jehane Benoît
entities.description: Jehane Benoît, was a Canadian culinary author, speaker, commentator, journalist, and broadcaster. After studying at the Sorbonne and Le Cordon Bleu cooking school in Paris, she started her own cooking school, Fumet de la Vieille France, in Montreal. She also opened one of Canada's first vegetarian restaurants, "The Salad Bar", in 1935.

heading: Deaths
txt: Juan Manuel Bordeu, Argentinian race car driver (b. 1934)

entities.title: Juan Manuel Bordeu
entities.description: Juan Manuel Bordeu was a racing driver from Balcarce, Argentina. A protégé of Juan Manuel Fangio, Bordeu had a successful early career but a bad testing accident wrecked his chances in Formula One. His only World Championship Formula One entry was at the 1961 French Grand Prix in a Lotus run by the UDT Laystall team, but the car was eventually driven by Lucien Bianchi.

heading: Deaths
txt: Fred Shero, Canadian ice hockey player and coach (b. 1925)

heading: Deaths
txt: Dodie Smith, English author and playwright (b. 1896)

heading: Deaths
txt: Marion Post Wolcott, American photographer (b. 1910)

heading: Deaths
txt: Bülent Arel, Turkish-American composer and educator (b. 1919)

heading: Deaths
txt: Freddie Mercury, Tanzanian-English singer-songwriter, lead vocalist of Queen, and producer (b. 1946)

entities.title: Freddie Mercury
entities.description: Freddie Mercury was a British singer, songwriter, record producer, and lead vocalist of the rock band Queen. Regarded as one of the greatest singers in the history of rock music, he was known for his flamboyant stage persona and four-octave vocal range. Mercury defied the conventions of a rock frontman, with his highly theatrical style influencing the artistic direction of Queen.

entities.title: Queen (band)
entities.description: Queen are a British rock band formed in London in 1970. Their classic line-up was Freddie Mercury, Brian May, Roger Taylor and John Deacon (bass). Their earliest works were influenced by progressive rock, hard rock and heavy metal, but the band gradually ventured into more conventional and radio-friendly works by incorporating further styles, such as arena rock and pop rock.

heading: Deaths
txt: Eric Carr, American drummer of KISS (b. 1950)

entities.title: Kiss (band)
entities.description: Kiss is an American rock band formed in New York City in January 1973 by Paul Stanley, Gene Simmons, Ace Frehley, and Peter Criss. Well known for its members' face paint and stage outfits, the group rose to prominence in the mid–late 1970s with its shocking live performances, which featured fire breathing, blood-spitting, smoking guitars, shooting rockets, levitating drum kits, and pyrotechnics. T

heading: Deaths
txt: Albert Collins, American singer-songwriter and guitarist (b. 1932)

entities.title: Albert Collins
entities.description: Albert Gene Drewery, known as Albert Collins and the Ice Man, was an American electric blues guitarist and singer with a distinctive guitar style. He was noted for his powerful playing and his use of altered tunings and a capo. His long association with the Fender Telecaster led to the title "The Master of the Telecaster".

heading: Deaths
txt: Eduard Ole, Estonian-Swedish painter (b. 1898)

entities.title: Eduard Ole
entities.description: Eduard Ole was an Estonian painter. Some of his most representative works are on permanent exhibition at the Kumu Art Museum of Estonia.

heading: Deaths
txt: Sorley MacLean, Scottish soldier and poet (b. 1911)

entities.title: Sorley MacLean
entities.description: Sorley MacLean was a Scottish Gaelic poet, described by the Scottish Poetry Library as "one of the major Scottish poets of the modern era" because of his "mastery of his chosen medium and his engagement with the European poetic tradition and European politics". Nobel Prize Laureate Seamus Heaney credited MacLean with saving Scottish Gaelic poetry.

heading: Deaths
txt: Barbara, French singer-songwriter and actress (b. 1930)

entities.title: Barbara (singer)
entities.description: Monique Andrée Serf was a French singer. She took her stage name, Barbara, from her grandmother, Varvara Brodsky, a native of Odessa, Russian Empire. Her song "L'Aigle noir" sold 1 million copies in twelve hours.

heading: Deaths
txt: John Rawls, American philosopher, author, and academic (b. 1921)

entities.title: John Rawls
entities.description: John Bordley Rawls was an American moral and political philosopher in the liberal tradition. Rawls received both the Schock Prize for Logic and Philosophy and the National Humanities Medal in 1999, the latter presented by President Bill Clinton, in recognition of how Rawls's work "helped a whole generation of learned Americans revive their faith in democracy itself."

heading: Deaths
txt: Warren Spahn, American baseball player and coach (b. 1921)

entities.title: Warren Spahn
entities.description: Warren Edward Spahn was an American professional baseball player. He played in Major League Baseball as a left-handed pitcher in 1942 and then from 1946 until 1965, most notably for the Boston Braves, who became the Milwaukee Braves after the team moved west before the 1953 season. His baseball career was interrupted by his military service in the United States Army during the Second World War.

heading: Deaths
txt: Arthur Hailey, English-Canadian journalist and author (b. 1920)

entities.title: Arthur Hailey
entities.description: Arthur Frederick Hailey was a British-Canadian novelist whose plot-driven storylines were set against the backdrops of various industries. His books, which include such best sellers as Hotel (1965), Airport (1968), Wheels (1971), The Moneychangers (1975), and Overload (1979), have sold 170 million copies in 38 languages.

heading: Deaths
txt: Joseph Hansen, American author and poet (b. 1923)

heading: Deaths
txt: James Wong, Chinese actor and songwriter (b. 1940)

heading: Deaths
txt: Pat Morita, American actor (b. 1932)

entities.title: Pat Morita
entities.description: Noriyuki "Pat" Morita was a Japanese-American actor and comedian. He was known for his roles as Matsuo "Arnold" Takahashi on Happy Days (1975–1983), Mr. Miyagi in The Karate Kid film series, Mike Woo in The Mystery Files of Shelby Woo, and The Emperor of China in Mulan and Mulan II. Morita was nominated for the 1984 Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor for his portrayal of Mr. Miyagi in The Kar

heading: Deaths
txt: Juice Leskinen, Finnish singer-songwriter (b. 1950)

entities.title: Juice Leskinen
entities.description: Juhani Juice Leskinen, better known as just Juice Leskinen, was one of the most prominent Finnish singer-songwriters of the late 20th century. From the early 1970s onward he released nearly 30 full-length albums, as well as writing song lyrics for dozens of Finnish artists. entities.title: Huang Hua
entities.description: Huang Hua was a senior Communist Chinese revolutionary, politician, and diplomat. He served as Foreign Minister of China from 1976 to 1982, and concurrently as Vice Premier from 1980 to 1982. He was instrumental in establishing diplomatic links of the People's Republic of China with the United States and Japan, and was intensely involved in the negotiations with the United Kingdom over the status

entities.title: Foreign Minister of the People's Republic of China
entities.description: The Minister of Foreign Affairs of the People's Republic of China is the head of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the People's Republic of China and one of the country's most important cabinet posts. The Minister usually is also a member of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China.

entities.title: Matthew Bucksbaum
entities.description: Matthew Bucksbaum was an American businessman and philanthropist. Matthew and his brothers Martin and Maurice co-founded General Growth Properties.

entities.title: General Growth Properties
entities.description: GGP Inc. was an American commercial real estate company and the second-largest shopping mall operator in the United States. It was founded by brothers Martin, Matthew and Maurice Bucksbaum in Cedar Rapids, Iowa in 1954, and has been headquartered in Chicago, Illinois since 2000. It was subject to the largest real estate bankruptcy in American history at the time of its filing in 2009.

entities.description: The Lieutenant Governor of Hawaii is the assistant chief executive of the U.S. state of Hawaii and its various agencies and departments, as provided in the Article V, Sections 2 though 6 of the Constitution of Hawaii. Elected by popular suffrage of residents of the state on the same ticket as the Governor of Hawaii, the officeholder is concurrently the Secretary of State of Hawaii.

entities.title: Goo Hara
entities.description: Goo Hara, also known mononymously as Hara, was a South Korean singer and actress. She was a member of the South Korean girl group Kara, and had also appeared in television dramas including City Hunter (2011). She made her debut as a soloist in July 2015 with the release of her EP Alohara .
